A motorcycle, often called a bike, motorbike, or cycle, is a two- or three-wheeled motor vehicle. Motorcycle design varies greatly to suit a range of different purposes: long distance travel, commuting, cruising, sport including racing, and off-road riding.

There are many different styles of motorcycles, including: Chopper, Bobber, Café racer, Cruiser, Touring, Sport bike, Standard, Dual-sport, Dirt bike, Scooter, Moped, Minibike, Pocket bike, Supermoto, and Motocross
A trike is a motorcycle that is powered by a single rear wheel.
A cruiser is a motorcycle in the style of American machines from the 1930s to the early 1960s, including those made by Harley-Davidson, Indian, Excelsior and Henderson.
The term cruiser has been used as a synonym for Harley-Davidson motorcycles, because of that company's long history of building heavy-duty, high-performance motorcycles with a "chopper" style.
A chopper is a type of custom motorcycle which emerged in California in the late 1950s.
The cruiser is a style of motorcycle that is designed to look good and feel comfortable for long distance riding.
A trike is a three-wheeled vehicle.

A chopper is a type of custom motorcycle which emerged in California in the late 1950s. The chopper is perhaps the most extreme of all custom styles, often using radically modified steering angles and lengthened forks for a stretched-out appearance.
The term chopper is sometimes used interchangeably with bobber, although the term is often used to describe a more extreme custom motorcycle.
A sidecar is a one-wheeled device attached to the side of a motorcycle, scooter, or bicycle, producing a three-wheeled vehicle.
The cafe racer is a light motorcycle with minimal bodywork and a single seat.
